content.text: A computer follows instructions to process information. It has hardware and software.

items: Hardware: the physical parts you can touch.
Software: the programs that tell the hardware what to do.

content.text: A quick, source-cited journey through key moments in computing. Citations are inline at the end of each item.

items: 1936 — Alan Turing formalizes computation with the Turing machine concept in “On Computable Numbers.” [Turing, 1936, Proc. Lond. Math. Soc.]
1945 — John von Neumann’s “First Draft of a Report on the EDVAC” outlines the stored-program architecture. [von Neumann, 1945]
1947/48 — Bell Labs demonstrates and publicly announces the first working transistor (point-contact), launching solid-state electronics. [Bell Labs/CHM timeline; IEEE Spectrum]
1957 — FORTRAN popularizes high-level programming for scientific computing (IBM). [General histories]
1969 — ARPANET goes live; the first host-to-host message is sent between UCLA and SRI. [Internet Society; ICANN blog; HISTORY.com]
1971 — Intel introduces the 4004, an early general-purpose microprocessor. [Intel; IEEE Spectrum; Wikipedia overview]
1973 — Xerox PARC builds the Alto, pioneering GUI, mouse, networking, and WYSIWYG concepts. [Computer History Museum]
1977 — Apple II brings color graphics and, with VisiCalc (1979), drives personal computing adoption. [Computer History Museum; Smithsonian]
1981 — IBM unveils the PC (Model 5150), standardizing the open, modular PC ecosystem. [IBM Archives; Smithsonian]
1983 — ARPANET cuts over to TCP/IP (“flag day”), cementing the Internet’s core protocol suite. [Internet Society; ARPANET history]
1989–1991 — Tim Berners-Lee proposes and launches the World Wide Web at CERN; public access follows. [CERN proposal & history]
1991 — Linus Torvalds announces Linux, catalyzing open-source OS development. [Torvalds announcement retrospectives]
1993 — NCSA Mosaic popularizes the graphical web browser with inline images. [NCSA; UIUC; Wikipedia/NCSA Mosaic]
1998 — Google is founded, scaling web search with PageRank. [Google company history; Stanford Eng.]
2007 — Apple introduces the iPhone, mainstreaming multi-touch smartphones and mobile apps. [Apple press release; AP recap]
2012 — “AlexNet” demonstrates deep CNNs’ breakthrough on ImageNet, igniting modern deep learning. [NeurIPS 2012 paper]
2017 — The Transformer architecture (“Attention Is All You Need”) reshapes NLP and beyond. [NeurIPS 2017; arXiv]
2022 — OpenAI releases ChatGPT, accelerating public adoption of large language models. [OpenAI blog, Nov. 30, 2022]

lessons.title: Consumer Online Platforms: AOL *  BBS * CompuServe * Prodigy

content.text: A concise, source-cited tour from dial-up BBS culture to mass-market online services.

items: 1978 — CBBS goes online in Chicago, often cited as the first public dial-up BBS (Ward Christensen & Randy Suess). [BBS history overviews]

Mid-1980s — Wildcat! BBS (Mustang Software) popularizes MS-DOS BBS hosting; commonly dated to 1986 for initial release, with a 1987 shareware launch noted in Mustang’s own history. [Wildcat! page; Mustang history]
1979–1980 — CompuServe opens a consumer dial-up service (initially as MicroNET via Radio Shack) and becomes a leading commercial online service through the 1980s–early 1990s. [CompuServe histories]

1984 → 1988/1990 — Prodigy is founded (as Trintex: IBM, Sears, CBS), rolls out regionally in 1988, then nationwide by 1990; early GUI, flat-rate pricing, and heavy consumer marketing. [Prodigy histories]

1985 → 1991–1999 — Quantum Computer Services (later America Online) launches consumer clients (DOS 1991, Windows 1992) and grows rapidly through the 1990s with bundled software and flat-rate plans. [AOL histories & 1990s data]
2025 — The dial-up era’s sunset: AOL announces end of dial-up service (Sept 30, 2025), closing a chapter that introduced millions to the Internet. [Recent news]

quiz.prompt: Which statement best matches the historical record?
choices: Prodigy launched nationwide in 1984 with built-in web browsing.
CompuServe opened a consumer service around 1979–1980 after starting as a corporate timesharing firm.
Wildcat! BBS was a Prodigy-owned GUI for Macintosh only.
AOL’s first general-availability client shipped in the 1970s.

content.text: Before the modern Web, communication relied on protocols and systems that carried messages across academic and commercial networks. This timeline highlights e-mail, Usenet, LISTSERV, and Gopher, which laid the foundation for today’s networked information systems.

items: 1971 — Ray Tomlinson sends the first networked e-mail using ARPANET and introduces the '@' symbol for addressing. [Internet Society, 2017; Wired, 2012]

1979–1980 — UUCP (Unix-to-Unix Copy) allows file transfer and mail exchange over dial-up links. Usenet is created for distributed discussions among UNIX systems. [Hafner & Lyon, 1996; UUCP overview, 2024]
1982 — SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) becomes the Internet standard for transmitting messages between mail servers (RFC 821). [Postel, 1982]
1986 — LISTSERV automates mailing list subscriptions, replacing manual management and enabling large-scale group communication. [L-Soft, 2020]
1986 — NNTP (Network News Transfer Protocol) extends Usenet to TCP/IP, allowing faster global distribution of newsgroups. [RFC 977; TLDP HOWTO]
1991 — Gopher launches at the University of Minnesota as a menu-driven information service before the rise of the Web. [University of Minnesota Archives, 2020]
1996 — MIME (Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions) extends e-mail for attachments and different text encodings, shaping modern e-mail formats. [Borenstein & Freed, 1996]
1996 — POP3 (Post Office Protocol v3) standardizes downloading mail to local clients, while IMAP enables multi-device synchronization. [Crispin, 1996; RFC 1939]
